Authors:
David Allan Orlovich, Suzy J Draffin, Robert Anthony Daly,
Steven L. Stephenson
Title:
Piracy in the high trees: ectomycorrhizal fungi from an
aerial “canopy soil” microhabitat
Keywords:
adventitious roots, canopy soil, ectomycorrhizas,
epiphytes, Nothofagus menziesii (silver beech), nutrient cycle
Abstract:
The mantle of dead organic material (“canopy soil”) often
associated with the mats of vascular and nonvascular epiphytes found on
the branches of trees in the temperate rainforests that occur along the
southwestern coast of the South Island of New Zealand were examined for
evidence of ectomycorrhizal fungi. DNA sequencing and cluster analysis
were used to identify the taxa of fungi present in 74 root tips
collected from the canopy soil microhabitat of three old-growth
Nothofagus menziesii trees in the South West New Zealand World Heritage
Area. A diverse assemblage of ectomycorrhizal fungi was found to infect
an extensive network of adventitious canopy roots of Nothofagus
menziesii in this old-growth forest, including 14 phylotypes across 9
genera of putative ectomycorrhizal fungi. Canopy ectomycorrhizas provide
an unexpected means for increased host nutrition that may have
functional significance in some forest ecosystems. Presumably, canopy
ectomycorrhizas circumvent the treegroundsoil nutrient cycle by
accessing a wider range of nutrients directly in the canopy than would
be possible for non-mycorrhizal or arbuscular mycorrhizal canopy roots.
In this system, both host and epiphytes would seem to be in competition
for the same pool of nutrients in canopy soil.
